qas.question: What do some organizations disagree with the notion of?
What do scholars also disagree with about the way the Supreme Court has interpreted what?
What do the critics argue the phrase misrepresents?

answers.text: the textual requirements of the Constitution

qas.question: What do critics note were intermingled at the time the Constitution was ratified?

answers.text: many aspects of church and state

qas.question: What do these critics argue couldn't have been intended by the framers of the constitution?

answers.text: prevalent degree of separation of church and state

qas.question: What do some organizations agree with the notion of?
What do scholars also agree with about the way the Supreme Court has interpreted what?
What don't the critics argue the phrase misrepresents?

plausible_answers.text: many aspects of church and state

qas.question: What do critics note were intermingled at the time the Constitution was not ratified?

plausible_answers.text: prevalent degree of separation of church and state

qas.question: What do these critics argue could have been intended by the framers of the constitution?

context: Some scholars and organizations disagree with the notion of "<a0_0><b5_0>separation of church and state<b5_0/><a0_0/>", or the way the Supreme Court has interpreted the <a1_0><b6_0>constitutional limitation on religious establishment<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Such critics generally argue that the phrase misrepresents <a2_0>the <b7_0>textual requirements of the Constitution<b7_0/><a2_0/>, while noting that <a3_0><b8_0>many aspects of church and state<b8_0/><a3_0/> were intermingled at the time the Constitution was ratified. These critics argue that the <a4_0><b9_0>prevalent degree of separation of church and state<b9_0/><a4_0/> could not have been intended by the constitutional framers. Some of the intermingling between church and state include religious references in official contexts, and such other founding documents as the United States Declaration of Independence, which references the idea of a "Creator" and "Nature's God", though these references did not ultimately appear in the Constitution nor do they mention any particular religious view of a "Creator" or "Nature's God."
